title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement codeofconduct@posit.co. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to rollout
text: outlines propose change rollout. detailed discussion contributing tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to rollout
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to rollout
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to rollout
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("iancero/rollout", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to rollout
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to rollout
text: Please note rollout project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

text: Thanks using rollout! filing issue, places explore pieces put together make process smooth possible.

title: Getting help with rollout
text: Start making minimal reproducible example using reprex package. haven’t heard used reprex , ’re treat! Seriously, reprex make R-question-asking endeavors easier (pretty incredible ROI five ten minutes ’ll take learn ’s ). additional reprex pointers, check Get help! section tidyverse site.

title: Getting help with rollout
text: Armed reprex, next step figure ask. ’s question: start community.rstudio.com, /StackOverflow. people answer questions. ’s bug: ’re right place, file issue. ’re sure: let community help figure ! problem bug feature request, can easily return report . opening new issue, sure search issues pull requests make sure bug hasn’t reported /already fixed development version. default, search pre-populated :issue :open. can edit qualifiers (e.g. :pr, :closed) needed. example, ’d simply remove :open search issues repo, open closed.

text: efficient possible, development tidyverse packages tends bursty, shouldn’t worry don’t get immediate response. Typically don’t look repo sufficient quantity issues accumulates, ’s burst intense activity focus efforts. makes development efficient avoids expensive context switching problems, cost taking longer get back . process makes good reprex particularly important might multiple months initial report start working . can’t reproduce bug, can’t fix !

title: Authors and Citation
text: Ian Cero. Author, maintainer. C. Hendricks Brown. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Cero , Brown C (2025). rollout: Tools Designing, Simulating, Analyzing Implementation Rollout Trials. R package version 0.1.0, https://github.com/iancero/rollout.
code: @Manual{,   title = {rollout: Tools for Designing, Simulating, and Analyzing Implementation Rollout Trials},   author = {Ian Cero and C. Hendricks Brown},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://github.com/iancero/rollout}, }

title: Tools for Designing, Simulating, and Analyzing Implementation Rollout Trials
text: Rollout trials, including stepped wedge sequential rollout designs, allow staggered implementation interventions across sites collecting outcome data time. designs increasingly used implementation science balance practical, ethical, statistical considerations rolling interventions real-world settings. rollout R package supports design analysis rollout trials using simulation-based methods. tutorial demonstrates simulate, analyze, estimate power stepped wedge trial multiple sites per cohort. workflow aligns following structure: Define rollout schedule across sites cohorts. Join unit-level information number participants per site. Specify simulation parameters intervention effects variance components. Simulate outcomes specified design. Fit models across multiple simulated replicates. Evaluate bias power planned design. following pipeline, can efficiently evaluate optimize rollout trial design conducting study.

title: Tools for Designing, Simulating, and Analyzing Implementation Rollout Trials
text: can install release version directly CRAN: , can install development version rollout directly GitHub using remotes package:
code: install.packages("rollout") # Install remotes package if needed install.packages("remotes")  # Install rollout from GitHub remotes::install_github("iancero/rollout")

title: Tools for Designing, Simulating, and Analyzing Implementation Rollout Trials
text: begin loading required packages setting seed reproducibility. Throughout tutorial, use tidyverse data manipulation plotting, rollout package design, simulation, evaluation rollout trials.
code: library(tidyverse) #> Warning: package 'tidyverse' was built under R version 4.5.2 #> Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.5.2 #> Warning: package 'purrr' was built under R version 4.5.2 #> Warning: package 'stringr' was built under R version 4.5.2 library(rollout)  set.seed(1234)  # for reproducibility

title: Tools for Designing, Simulating, and Analyzing Implementation Rollout Trials
text: simulate stepped wedge rollout trial : 4 cohorts 8 sites total (2 per cohort) 8 timepoints cohort transitions intervention ("intv") different time data collected continuously. use tribble() clarity, convert long format using pivot_schedule_longer().
code: # Create a stepped wedge schedule with 8 sites, 4 cohorts, 8 timepoints rollout_schedule <- tribble(   ~cohort, ~site, ~t1, ~t2, ~t3, ~t4, ~t5, ~t6, ~t7, ~t8,        1,    "A",  "ctrl", "ctrl", "intv",  "intv", "intv", "intv", "intv", "intv",        1,    "B",  "ctrl", "ctrl", "intv",  "intv", "intv", "intv", "intv", "intv",        2,    "C",  "ctrl", "ctrl",  "ctrl", "intv", "intv", "intv", "intv", "intv",        2,    "D",  "ctrl", "ctrl",  "ctrl", "intv", "intv", "intv", "intv", "intv",        3,    "E",  "ctrl", "ctrl", "ctrl", "ctrl",  "intv", "intv", "intv", "intv",        3,    "F",  "ctrl", "ctrl", "ctrl", "ctrl",  "intv", "intv", "intv", "intv",        4,    "G",  "ctrl", "ctrl", "ctrl", "ctrl", "ctrl", "ctrl",  "intv", "intv",        4,    "H",  "ctrl", "ctrl", "ctrl", "ctrl", "ctrl", "ctrl",  "intv", "intv" )  # Transform to long format for simulation long_schedule <- rollout_schedule |>   pivot_schedule_longer(time_cols = starts_with("t"))  # Preview structure long_schedule |>    head() #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>   cohort site  chron_time condition local_time #>    <dbl> <chr>      <dbl> <fct>          <dbl> #> 1      1 A              1 ctrl               0 #> 2      1 A              2 ctrl               1 #> 3      1 A              3 intv               0 #> 4      1 A              4 intv               1 #> 5      1 A              5 intv               2 #> 6      1 A              6 intv               3

title: Tools for Designing, Simulating, and Analyzing Implementation Rollout Trials
text: Next, specify unit-level information site, sometimes available advance trial. example, site slightly different number units, reflecting real-world differences site sizes. join information long-format rollout schedule using join_info(). expand dataset include row unit timepoint.
code: # Create unit-level information with variable site sizes unit_info <- tribble(   ~site, ~n_units,    "A",   18,    "B",   22,    "C",   20,    "D",   19,    "E",   21,    "F",   20,    "G",   23,    "H",   17 )  # Join unit-level info to the long-format schedule design_df <- join_info(   long_schedule,   unit_info = unit_info,   by = "site",   uncount_vars = "n_units",   .ids = "unit_id" )  # Preview the expanded design design_df |>    head() #> # A tibble: 6 × 6 #>   cohort site  chron_time condition local_time unit_id #>    <dbl> <chr>      <dbl> <fct>          <dbl>   <int> #> 1      1 A              1 ctrl               0       1 #> 2      1 A              1 ctrl               0       2 #> 3      1 A              1 ctrl               0       3 #> 4      1 A              1 ctrl               0       4 #> 5      1 A              1 ctrl               0       5 #> 6      1 A              1 ctrl               0       6

title: Tools for Designing, Simulating, and Analyzing Implementation Rollout Trials
text: now add simulation parameters design. key advantage rollout ability expand parameter grid, enabling evaluation multiple scenarios within simulation pipeline. example: - evaluate two intervention effect sizes (b_intv = 0.2 small effect, b_intv = 0.5 moderate effect). - specify constant site-level standard deviation (sigma_site = 0.5) unit-level residual standard deviation (sigma_unit = 1).
code: design_df <- design_df |>   add_parameter(     b_intv = c(0.2, 0.5),     sigma_site = 0.5,     sigma_unit = 1   )  # Preview to confirm parameter expansion design_df |>    head() #> # A tibble: 6 × 9 #>   cohort site  chron_time condition local_time unit_id b_intv sigma_site #>    <dbl> <chr>      <dbl> <fct>          <dbl>   <int>  <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1      1 A              1 ctrl               0       1    0.2        0.5 #> 2      1 A              1 ctrl               0       1    0.5        0.5 #> 3      1 A              1 ctrl               0       2    0.2        0.5 #> 4      1 A              1 ctrl               0       2    0.5        0.5 #> 5      1 A              1 ctrl               0       3    0.2        0.5 #> 6      1 A              1 ctrl               0       3    0.5        0.5 #> # ℹ 1 more variable: sigma_unit <dbl>

title: Tools for Designing, Simulating, and Analyzing Implementation Rollout Trials
text: adding simulation parameters, expand design include replicates. enables us simulate multiple trials design estimate power evaluate bias efficiently. , use 10 replicates keep example lightweight. practice, number replicates chosen based precision want power estimate. common guideline : n = p*(1-p)/(se^2), se desired standard error power estimate p target power (example, p = 0.80).
code: design_df <- design_df |>   initialize_replicates(n = 10)  # Preview structure with replicate IDs design_df |>    head() #> # A tibble: 6 × 10 #>   sample_id cohort site  chron_time condition local_time unit_id b_intv #>       <int>  <dbl> <chr>      <dbl> <fct>          <dbl>   <int>  <dbl> #> 1         1      1 A              1 ctrl               0       1    0.2 #> 2         2      1 A              1 ctrl               0       1    0.2 #> 3         3      1 A              1 ctrl               0       1    0.2 #> 4         4      1 A              1 ctrl               0       1    0.2 #> 5         5      1 A              1 ctrl               0       1    0.2 #> 6         6      1 A              1 ctrl               0       1    0.2 #> # ℹ 2 more variables: sigma_site <dbl>, sigma_unit <dbl>

title: Tools for Designing, Simulating, and Analyzing Implementation Rollout Trials
text: now simulate outcome data according specified design. prepares dataset model fitting, power estimation, bias evaluation.

title: Tools for Designing, Simulating, and Analyzing Implementation Rollout Trials
text: First, add small negative time trend (b_time = -0.05) represent gradual improvement time, independent intervention.
code: design_df <- design_df |>   add_parameter(b_time = -0.05)

title: Tools for Designing, Simulating, and Analyzing Implementation Rollout Trials
text: Next, add fixed effects : - intervention effect, applied condition == "intv". - time trend, scaled chron_time.
code: design_df <- design_df |>   add_fixed_effect(     intv_effect = b_intv * as.numeric(condition == "intv")) |>   add_fixed_effect(     time_trend = b_time * chron_time)

title: Tools for Designing, Simulating, and Analyzing Implementation Rollout Trials
text: add random intercept site level simulate -site variability.
code: design_df <- design_df |>   add_random_effect(     site_intercept = rnorm(1, mean = 0, sd = sigma_site),     .nesting = "site"   )

title: Tools for Designing, Simulating, and Analyzing Implementation Rollout Trials
text: add unit-level residual error variance sigma_unit^2.
code: design_df <- design_df |>   add_error(variance = sigma_unit^2)

title: Tools for Designing, Simulating, and Analyzing Implementation Rollout Trials
text: Finally, generate linear outcome (y_linear) summing fixed, random, error components.
code: design_df <- design_df |>   add_linear_outcome(output_col = "y_linear")  # Preview simulated data design_df |>    head() #> # A tibble: 6 × 16 #>   sample_id cohort site  chron_time condition local_time unit_id b_intv #>       <int>  <dbl> <chr>      <dbl> <fct>          <dbl>   <int>  <dbl> #> 1         1      1 A              1 ctrl               0       1    0.2 #> 2         2      1 A              1 ctrl               0       1    0.2 #> 3         3      1 A              1 ctrl               0       1    0.2 #> 4         4      1 A              1 ctrl               0       1    0.2 #> 5         5      1 A              1 ctrl               0       1    0.2 #> 6         6      1 A              1 ctrl               0       1    0.2 #> # ℹ 8 more variables: sigma_site <dbl>, sigma_unit <dbl>, b_time <dbl>, #> #   .intv_effect <dbl>, .time_trend <dbl>, .site_intercept <dbl>, .error <dbl>, #> #   y_linear <dbl>

title: Tools for Designing, Simulating, and Analyzing Implementation Rollout Trials
text: simulated outcomes generated, now fit planned analysis model across replicates parameter scenarios. process automatically conducted parallel, ’ll need load packages parallel process explicitly (see line packages = "lmerTest"). example: - use linear mixed-effects models account site-level clustering. - model includes: - condition (intervention vs control), - chron_time (continuous time trend), - random intercept site. - group sample_id (replicates) b_intv (effect size scenario). approach allows us evaluate bias power across replicates effect size conditions.
code: fitted_models <- design_df |>   group_by(sample_id, b_intv) |>   nest() |>   ungroup() |>    fit_models(     .x = data,     .f = ~ lmer(       formula = y_linear ~ condition + chron_time + (1 | site),       data = .x),     packages = "lmerTest") # load lmerTest in each parallel process  fitted_models |>    head() #> # A tibble: 6 × 4 #> Loading required namespace: lmerTest #>   sample_id b_intv data                  model      #>       <int>  <dbl> <list>                <list>     #> 1         1    0.2 <tibble [1,280 × 14]> <lmrMdLmT> #> 2         2    0.2 <tibble [1,280 × 14]> <lmrMdLmT> #> 3         3    0.2 <tibble [1,280 × 14]> <lmrMdLmT> #> 4         4    0.2 <tibble [1,280 × 14]> <lmrMdLmT> #> 5         5    0.2 <tibble [1,280 × 14]> <lmrMdLmT> #> 6         6    0.2 <tibble [1,280 × 14]> <lmrMdLmT>

title: Tools for Designing, Simulating, and Analyzing Implementation Rollout Trials
text: fitting models, now extract key results evaluate bias power intervention effect. : - Extract model estimates using extract_model_results(). - Summarize power calculating proportion p-values .05 (done default evaluate_model_results). - **Summarize bias** intervention effect usingeval_bias(). - **Estimate critical value** calculating observed value b-estimates 97.5th percentile, usingeval_quantile()`.
code: # Extract tidy model results model_results <- fitted_models |>   extract_model_results()  # Summarize bias and power summary_results <- model_results |>   group_by(b_intv, term) |>   evaluate_model_results(     bias = eval_bias(estimate, term = c("(Intercept)" = 0, conditionintv = b_intv)),     critical_val = eval_quantile(estimate, term = c("conditionintv" = 0.975))   )  # View summary of bias and power summary_results #> # A tibble: 10 × 8 #> # Groups:   b_intv [2] #>    b_intv term   n_models mean_estimate mean_std.error power   bias critical_val #>     <dbl> <chr>     <int>         <dbl>          <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>        <dbl> #>  1    0.2 (Inte…       10       -0.155          0.207    0   -0.155       NA     #>  2    0.2 chron…       10       -0.0444         0.0207   0.6 NA           NA     #>  3    0.2 condi…       10        0.177          0.102    0.6 NA            0.328 #>  4    0.2 sd__(…       10       NA             NA       NA   NA           NA     #>  5    0.2 sd__O…       10       NA             NA       NA   NA           NA     #>  6    0.5 (Inte…       10       -0.192          0.208    0   -0.192       NA     #>  7    0.5 chron…       10       -0.0404         0.0206   0.5 NA           NA     #>  8    0.5 condi…       10        0.484          0.102    1   NA            0.590 #>  9    0.5 sd__(…       10       NA             NA       NA   NA           NA     #> 10    0.5 sd__O…       10       NA             NA       NA   NA           NA

what: Create a binary outcome from linear predictors — add_binary_outcome
title: Create a binary outcome from linear predictors — add_binary_outcome
text: Generates binary outcome summing effects, computing probabilities via logistic function, drawing binary outcomes.

title: Create a binary outcome from linear predictors — add_binary_outcome
code: add_binary_outcome(   data,   linear_col = "y_linear",   prob_col = "y_prob",   binary_col = "y_bin" )

title: Create a binary outcome from linear predictors — add_binary_outcome
text: data data frame containing effect columns prefixed ".". linear_col Name column store summed linear predictor (default "y_linear"). prob_col Name column store probabilities (default "y_prob"). binary_col Name column store binary outcomes (default "y_bin").

title: Create a binary outcome from linear predictors — add_binary_outcome
text: tibble added linear predictor, probability, binary outcome columns.

title: Create a binary outcome from linear predictors — add_binary_outcome

what: Add an error term for simulation — add_error
title: Add an error term for simulation — add_error
text: Adds residual error term (column .error) data frame, drawn normal distribution specified variance.

title: Add an error term for simulation — add_error
code: add_error(.data, variance = 1)

title: Add an error term for simulation — add_error
text: .data data frame error term added. variance Numeric; variance residual error (default 1).

title: Add an error term for simulation — add_error
text: tibble added .error column.

title: Add an error term for simulation — add_error
code: df <- tibble::tibble(x = 1:5) add_error(df, variance = 2) #> # A tibble: 5 × 2 #>       x .error #>   <int>  <dbl> #> 1     1  0.695 #> 2     2 -1.07  #> 3     3  0.494 #> 4     4 -0.242 #> 5     5  2.31

what: Add a fixed effect column for simulation — add_fixed_effect
title: Add a fixed effect column for simulation — add_fixed_effect
text: Adds fixed effect column (prefixed ".") design data frame simulation purposes.

title: Add a fixed effect column for simulation — add_fixed_effect
code: add_fixed_effect(design_df, ...)

title: Add a fixed effect column for simulation — add_fixed_effect
text: design_df data frame containing rollout design parameters. ... single named expression specifying fixed effect add (e.g., beta = 0.5 * x).

title: Add a fixed effect column for simulation — add_fixed_effect
text: tibble added fixed effect column.

title: Add a fixed effect column for simulation — add_fixed_effect

what: Create a linear outcome by summing effects — add_linear_outcome
title: Create a linear outcome by summing effects — add_linear_outcome
text: Generates linear outcome variable summing columns start "." (representing fixed, random, error effects).

title: Create a linear outcome by summing effects — add_linear_outcome
code: add_linear_outcome(data, output_col = "y_linear")

title: Create a linear outcome by summing effects — add_linear_outcome
text: data data frame containing effect columns prefixed ".". output_col Name column store linear outcome (default "y_linear").

title: Create a linear outcome by summing effects — add_linear_outcome
text: tibble added linear outcome column.

title: Create a linear outcome by summing effects — add_linear_outcome

what: Expand a data frame with parameter combinations for simulation — add_parameter
title: Expand a data frame with parameter combinations for simulation — add_parameter
text: Adds combinations specified parameter values data frame simulation expanding combinations.

title: Expand a data frame with parameter combinations for simulation — add_parameter
code: add_parameter(df, ...)

title: Expand a data frame with parameter combinations for simulation — add_parameter
text: df data frame expand. ... Named vectors specifying parameter values expand, provided param_name = values.

title: Expand a data frame with parameter combinations for simulation — add_parameter
text: tibble added parameter columns combination values.

title: Expand a data frame with parameter combinations for simulation — add_parameter
code: df <- tibble::tibble(site = "A", condition = "control") add_parameter(df, beta = c(0, 0.5), sigma = c(1, 2)) #> # A tibble: 4 × 4 #>   site  condition  beta sigma #>   <chr> <chr>     <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 A     control     0       1 #> 2 A     control     0       2 #> 3 A     control     0.5     1 #> 4 A     control     0.5     2

title: Create a Poisson outcome from linear predictors — add_poisson_outcome
code: add_poisson_outcome(   data,   linear_col = "y_linear",   rate_col = "y_rate",   count_col = "y_count" )

title: Create a Poisson outcome from linear predictors — add_poisson_outcome
text: data data frame containing effect columns prefixed ".". linear_col Name column store summed linear predictor (default "y_linear"). rate_col Name column store Poisson rates (default "y_rate"). count_col Name column store Poisson counts (default "y_count").

what: Add a random effect column for simulation — add_random_effect
title: Add a random effect column for simulation — add_random_effect
text: Adds random effect column (prefixed ".") design data frame, optional grouping nested random effects.

title: Add a random effect column for simulation — add_random_effect
code: add_random_effect(design_df, ..., .nesting = NULL)

title: Add a random effect column for simulation — add_random_effect
text: design_df data frame containing rollout design parameters. ... single named expression specifying random effect add (e.g., u = rnorm(1, 0, 1)). .nesting Optional character vector specifying grouping columns nested random effects (default NULL).

title: Add a random effect column for simulation — add_random_effect
text: tibble added random effect column.

title: Add a random effect column for simulation — add_random_effect
code: df <- tibble::tibble(site = rep(1:2, each = 3)) add_random_effect(df, u = rnorm(1, 0, 1), .nesting = "site") #> # A tibble: 6 × 2 #>    site      .u #>   <int>   <dbl> #> 1     1 -0.206  #> 2     1 -0.206  #> 3     1 -0.206  #> 4     2  0.0192 #> 5     2  0.0192 #> 6     2  0.0192

what: Compute the proportion of values within term-specific intervals within grouped simulation results — eval_between
title: Compute the proportion of values within term-specific intervals within grouped simulation results — eval_between
text: Computes proportion x values falling within term-specific intervals within group, typically inside evaluate_model_results() simulation evaluation pipelines.

title: Compute the proportion of values within term-specific intervals within grouped simulation results — eval_between
code: eval_between(x, term = NULL, na.rm = FALSE)

title: Compute the proportion of values within term-specific intervals within grouped simulation results — eval_between
text: x numeric vector estimates statistics. term named list numeric vectors length 2, giving lower upper bounds term. example, list("(Intercept)" = c(-1, 1), x = c(1, 3)). NULL (default), interval assumed [0, 1]. na.rm Logical; whether remove missing values computing proportion. Defaults FALSE.

title: Compute the proportion of values within term-specific intervals within grouped simulation results — eval_between
text: numeric scalar representing proportion x within term-specific interval within current group.

title: Compute the proportion of values within term-specific intervals within grouped simulation results — eval_between
text: function designed used inside dplyr::summarise() within grouped tidyverse pipeline, typically grouping term. term provided, current grouping must include term variable matching names term. term group found provided term mapping, function return NA warning.

title: Compute the proportion of values within term-specific intervals within grouped simulation results — eval_between

what: Summarise simulation results from extracted model estimates — evaluate_model_results
title: Summarise simulation results from extracted model estimates — evaluate_model_results
text: Computes summary statistics (e.g., power, custom summaries) across set extracted model results, typically extract_model_results(), facilitate simulation evaluation reporting.

title: Summarise simulation results from extracted model estimates — evaluate_model_results
code: evaluate_model_results(   results,   alpha = 0.05,   ...,   .summarise_standard_broom = FALSE,   broom_cols = c("estimate", "std.error", "statistic", "df", "p.value") )

title: Summarise simulation results from extracted model estimates — evaluate_model_results
text: results data frame extracted model results, typically including columns like term, estimate, std.error, statistic, p.value. alpha Significance level used compute power. Defaults 0.05. ... Additional summary expressions compute within dplyr::summarise(). may include calls helper functions like eval_bias(), eval_quantile(), direct summaries mean(estimate, na.rm = TRUE). .summarise_standard_broom Logical; TRUE, computes mean standard deviation standard broom columns present data (columns broom_cols). Defaults FALSE. broom_cols Character vector standard broom columns summarise .summarise_standard_broom = TRUE. Defaults c("estimate", "std.error", "statistic", "df", "p.value").

title: Summarise simulation results from extracted model estimates — evaluate_model_results
text: summarised data frame containing: n_models: number models summarised. power: proportion p-values less alpha (NA p-values NA). Additional columns corresponding custom summaries provided .... Mean SD summaries broom columns .summarise_standard_broom = TRUE.

what: Extract and tidy model results from a column of models — extract_model_results
title: Extract and tidy model results from a column of models — extract_model_results
text: Applies tidying function (default broom.mixed::tidy) column models, returning tidy data frame one row per term per model, suitable downstream summarisation evaluation simulation studies.

title: Extract and tidy model results from a column of models — extract_model_results
code: extract_model_results(   models,   model_col = "model",   tidy_fun = broom.mixed::tidy,   .term = NULL )

title: Extract and tidy model results from a column of models — extract_model_results
text: models data frame containing column fitted model objects. model_col Unquoted column name containing models. Default model. tidy_fun tidying function apply model. Default broom.mixed::tidy. function must return data frame term column. .term Optional string specifying term filter tidying (e.g., "(Intercept)"). NULL (default), terms retained.

title: Extract and tidy model results from a column of models — extract_model_results
text: tidy data frame original columns models joined tidied model results, typically including columns term, estimate, std.error, statistic, p.value.

title: Extract and tidy model results from a column of models — extract_model_results
code: library(dplyr) library(purrr) library(broom.mixed)  # Simulate and fit models sim_models <- tibble(   id = 1:5,   model = map(1:5, ~ lm(mpg ~ wt, data = mtcars)) )  # Extract all terms extract_model_results(sim_models) #> # A tibble: 10 × 7 #>       id model  term        estimate std.error statistic  p.value #>    <int> <list> <chr>          <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>    <dbl> #>  1     1 <lm>   (Intercept)    37.3      1.88      19.9  8.24e-19 #>  2     1 <lm>   wt             -5.34     0.559     -9.56 1.29e-10 #>  3     2 <lm>   (Intercept)    37.3      1.88      19.9  8.24e-19 #>  4     2 <lm>   wt             -5.34     0.559     -9.56 1.29e-10 #>  5     3 <lm>   (Intercept)    37.3      1.88      19.9  8.24e-19 #>  6     3 <lm>   wt             -5.34     0.559     -9.56 1.29e-10 #>  7     4 <lm>   (Intercept)    37.3      1.88      19.9  8.24e-19 #>  8     4 <lm>   wt             -5.34     0.559     -9.56 1.29e-10 #>  9     5 <lm>   (Intercept)    37.3      1.88      19.9  8.24e-19 #> 10     5 <lm>   wt             -5.34     0.559     -9.56 1.29e-10  # Extract only the slope term extract_model_results(sim_models, .term = "wt") #> Error in dplyr::filter(results, rlang::.data$term == .term): ℹ In argument: `rlang::.data$term == .term`. #> Caused by error in `extract_model_results()`: #> ! Can't subset `.data` outside of a data mask context.

what: Fit models in parallel across a list-column of datasets — fit_models
title: Fit models in parallel across a list-column of datasets — fit_models
text: Applies user-specified model-fitting function element list-column datasets .data, fitting models parallel progress bar, returns original data frame new model column containing fitted models.

title: Fit models in parallel across a list-column of datasets — fit_models
code: fit_models(   .data,   .x,   .f,   packages = NULL,   n_cores = parallel::detectCores() - 1 )

title: Fit models in parallel across a list-column of datasets — fit_models
text: .data data frame containing list-column datasets model function applied. .x Unquoted column name list-column containing datasets. .f function formula apply dataset fit desired model (e.g., ~ lm(y ~ x, data = .) ~ lme4::lmer(y ~ x + (x | group), data = .)). packages character vector package names load parallel worker, model-fitting function requires additional packages. Defaults NULL. n_cores Number cores use parallel processing. Defaults parallel::detectCores() - 1.

title: Fit models in parallel across a list-column of datasets — fit_models
text: original .data data frame additional model column containing fitted model objects returned .f.

title: Fit models in parallel across a list-column of datasets — fit_models
text: function intended use simulation pipelines multiple datasets generated (e.g., via simulate_datasets()), models need fitted dataset efficiently parallel. uses pbapply::pblapply() provide progress bar model fitting, parallel::makeCluster() multi-core processing. Packages specified packages loaded worker ensure model-fitting functions depend packages work correctly parallel.

title: Fit models in parallel across a list-column of datasets — fit_models
code: library(dplyr) library(purrr) library(lme4) #> Loading required package: Matrix  # Create example grouped datasets for mixed models datasets <- tibble(   id = 1:5,   data = map(1:5, ~ {     df <- sleepstudy[sample(nrow(sleepstudy), 50, replace = TRUE), ]     df$Subject <- factor(df$Subject)     df   }) )  # Fit linear mixed models in parallel fitted_models <- fit_models(   datasets,   .x = data,   .f = ~ lme4::lmer(Reaction ~ Days + (Days | Subject), data = .),   packages = c("lme4") )  # Inspect the first fitted mixed model summary(fitted_models$model[[1]]) #> Linear mixed model fit by REML ['lmerMod'] #> Formula: Reaction ~ Days + (Days | Subject) #>    Data: . #>  #> REML criterion at convergence: 462.4 #>  #> Scaled residuals:  #>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max  #> -2.06752 -0.30054 -0.02271  0.36166  1.90815  #>  #> Random effects: #>  Groups   Name        Variance Std.Dev. Corr  #>  Subject  (Intercept) 714.49   26.730         #>           Days         55.67    7.461   -0.10 #>  Residual             211.52   14.544         #> Number of obs: 50, groups:  Subject, 18 #>  #> Fixed effects: #>             Estimate Std. Error t value #> (Intercept)  247.973      8.057  30.776 #> Days           9.881      2.268   4.356 #>  #> Correlation of Fixed Effects: #>      (Intr) #> Days -0.377  # Tidy the fitted models using extract_model_results() for further evaluation extracted <- extract_model_results(fitted_models) head(extracted) #> # what: Add replicate identifiers for simulation replicates — initialize_replicates
title: Add replicate identifiers for simulation replicates — initialize_replicates
text: Expands long-format schedule include replicate identifier running multiple simulation replicates efficiently.

title: Add replicate identifiers for simulation replicates — initialize_replicates
code: initialize_replicates(long_schedule, n)

title: Add replicate identifiers for simulation replicates — initialize_replicates
text: long_schedule long-format rollout schedule. n Integer specifying number replicates generate.

title: Add replicate identifiers for simulation replicates — initialize_replicates
text: tibble added sample_id column replicate indexing.

title: Add replicate identifiers for simulation replicates — initialize_replicates
code: schedule <- tibble::tibble(site = "A", cohort = 1, chron_time = 0, condition = "control") initialize_replicates(schedule, n = 3) #> # A tibble: 3 × 5 #>   sample_id site  cohort chron_time condition #>       <int> <chr>  <dbl>      <dbl> <chr>     #> 1         1 A          1          0 control   #> 2         2 A          1          0 control   #> 3         3 A          1          0 control

what: Join unit-level information to a long-format rollout schedule — join_info
title: Join unit-level information to a long-format rollout schedule — join_info
text: Merges unit-level characteristics parameters long-format rollout schedule optionally expands rows based count variables create multiple units per site.

title: Join unit-level information to a long-format rollout schedule — join_info
code: join_info(   long_schedule,   unit_info,   by = NULL,   uncount_vars = NULL,   .ids = NULL )

title: Join unit-level information to a long-format rollout schedule — join_info
text: long_schedule long-format schedule (output pivot_schedule_longer). unit_info data frame unit-level information join. Columns used join long_schedule unit_info (default NULL uses shared columns). uncount_vars Optional character vector list quosures indicating count variables expand rows. .ids Optional character vector specifying names id columns uncounting, one per uncount_var.

title: Join unit-level information to a long-format rollout schedule — join_info
text: tibble joined optionally expanded rows reflect unit counts.

title: Join unit-level information to a long-format rollout schedule — join_info
code: schedule <- tibble::tibble(site = "A", cohort = 1, chron_time = 0, condition = "control") unit_info <- tibble::tibble(site = "A", n_units = 3) join_info(schedule, unit_info, by = "site", uncount_vars = "n_units") #> # A tibble: 3 × 5 #>   site  cohort chron_time condition n_units_id #>   <chr>  <dbl>      <dbl> <chr>          <int> #> 1 A          1          0 control            1 #> 2 A          1          0 control            2 #> 3 A          1          0 control            3

what: Pivot a rollout schedule from wide to long format with local time calculation — pivot_schedule_longer
title: Pivot a rollout schedule from wide to long format with local time calculation — pivot_schedule_longer
text: Transforms wide-format rollout schedule long-format schedule, extracting chronological time column names, converting condition columns factors, adding local time within cohort desired.

title: Pivot a rollout schedule from wide to long format with local time calculation — pivot_schedule_longer
code: pivot_schedule_longer(   schedule,   time_cols,   names_to = "chron_time",   names_pattern = ".*(\\d+)",   names_transform = as.numeric,   values_to = "condition",   values_transform = as.factor,   cohort_name = "cohort",   local_time = TRUE )

title: Pivot a rollout schedule from wide to long format with local time calculation — pivot_schedule_longer
text: schedule data frame containing rollout schedule wide format. time_cols Columns containing time-specific condition assignments (tidyselect syntax). names_to Name new column store extracted chronological time (default "chron_time"). names_pattern Regular expression extract numeric time column names (default ".*(\\d+)"). names_transform Function transform extracted time values (default .numeric). values_to Name new column store condition values (default "condition"). values_transform Function transform condition values (default .factor). cohort_name column indicating cohort membership local time calculation (default cohort). local_time Logical; TRUE, adds local_time column indicating time since rollout start cohort condition (default TRUE).

title: Pivot a rollout schedule from wide to long format with local time calculation — pivot_schedule_longer
text: long-format tibble columns cohort, condition, chronological time, optionally local time.

title: Pivot a rollout schedule from wide to long format with local time calculation — pivot_schedule_longer
code: library(dplyr) library(tidyr) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘tidyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:Matrix’: #>  #>     expand, pack, unpack schedule <- tibble::tibble(   site = c("A", "B"),   cohort = c(1, 2),   t1 = c("control", "intervention"),   t2 = c("intervention", "intervention") ) pivot_schedule_longer(schedule, time_cols = starts_with("t")) #> Error in dplyr::group_by(schedule, rlang::.data[[cohort_name_char]], rlang::.data[[values_to]]): ℹ In argument: `rlang::.data[[cohort_name_char]]`. #> Caused by error in `pivot_schedule_longer()`: #> ! Can't subset `.data` outside of a data mask context.

what: rollout: Tools for Designing, Simulating, and Analyzing Implementation Rollout Trials — rollout-package
title: rollout: Tools for Designing, Simulating, and Analyzing Implementation Rollout Trials — rollout-package
text: Provides unified framework designing, simulating, analyzing implementation rollout trials, including stepped wedge, sequential rollout, head--head, multi-condition, rollout implementation optimization designs. package enables users flexibly specify rollout schedules, incorporate site-level nested data structures, generate outcomes rich hierarchical models, evaluate analytic strategies simulation-based power analysis. separating data generation model fitting, tools support assessment bias, Type error, robustness model misspecification. workflow integrates standard mixed-effects modeling approaches tidyverse ecosystem, offering transparent reproducible tools implementation scientists applied statisticians.

title: rollout: Tools for Designing, Simulating, and Analyzing Implementation Rollout Trials — rollout-package
text: Maintainer: Ian Cero ian_cero@urmc.rochester.edu (ORCID) Authors: C. Hendricks Brown hendricks.brown@northwestern.edu (ORCID)

title: rollout 0.1.0
text: Initial CRAN submission.
